thread.title: Aussie stocks follow global markets lower as investors focus on political upheaval
thread.title_full: Aussie stocks follow global markets lower as investors focus on political upheaval | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: MITCHELL NEEMS
title: Aussie stocks follow global markets lower as investors focus on political upheaval
text:
THE Australian sharemarket has followed global markets lower as investors briefly take their eyes off the looming US Federal Reserve meeting to focus on Malcolm Turnbull's ascendancy.
At 10.15am, the benchmark ASX 200 was down 15 points, or 0.3 per cent, at 5081.5 points, while the broader All Ordinaries was off 14.9 points, also 0.3 per cent, at 5105.6 points.
The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industrywelcomed the arrival of a prime minister with a track record in business, and analysts said the elevation of Malcolm Turnbull to replace the unpopular Tony Abbott could lift consumer and economic confidence.
IG market analyst Angus Nicholson said Mr Turnbull's promise of a more collegiate and considered style of governing would go over well.
“If it does provide a boost to confidence, that can also boost the real economy,” Mr Nicholson said.
The Australian dollar rallied late Monday against its US counterpart as Mr Turnbull's ultimately successful move to oust Mr Abbott gathered pace.
In economic news on Tuesday, the Reserve Bank of Australia releases the minutes of its September board meeting, the Australian Bureau of Statistics releases August new motor vehicles sales figures and the ANZ-Roy Morgan weekly consumer confidence survey is due out.
In equities news, Brambles has an investor briefing.
The local market ended higher on Monday ahead of the US Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates on Friday morning.
The benchmark ASX 200 index was up 25.4 points, or 0.5 per cent, at 5096.5 points.
The broader All Ordinaries index was up 24.2 points, or 0.47 per cent, at 5120.5 points.
Originally published as Aussie stocks open weaker
